dublinCore.dc:title: 119 HR 4171 IH: Small Entrepreneurs’ Empowerment and Development Act of 2025
dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.

action.action-desc: Mr. Garbarino introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Financial Services

form.official-title: To amend the Securities Act of 1933 to provide small issuers with a micro-offering exemption free of mandated disclosures or offering filings, but subject to the antifraud provisions of the Federal securities laws, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Small Entrepreneurs’ Empowerment and Development Act of 2025 or the SEED Act of 2025.

subsection.text: Section 4 of the Securities Act of 1933 (15 U.S.C. 77d) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subsection (a), by adding at the end the following:
transactions meeting the requirements of subsection (f).
by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: The transactions referred to in subsection (a)(8) are transactions involving the sale of securities by an issuer (including all entities controlled by or under common control with the issuer) where the aggregate amount of all securities sold by the issuer, including any amount sold in reliance on the exemption provided under subsection (a)(8), during the 12-month period preceding such transaction, does not exceed $250,000.

paragraph.text: Not later than 270 days after the date of enactment of this Act, the Securities and Exchange Commission shall, by rule, establish disqualification provisions under which an issuer shall not be eligible to offer securities pursuant to section 4(a)(8) of the Securities Act of 1933, as added by this section.
Disqualification provisions required by this subsection shall—

subparagraph.text: be substantially similar to the provisions of section 230.506(d) of title 17, Code of Federal Regulations (or any successor thereto); and
disqualify any offering or sale of securities by a person that—

clause.text: is subject to a final order of a covered regulator that—

item.text: association with an entity regulated by the covered regulator;
engaging in the business of securities, insurance, or banking; or
engaging in savings association or credit union activities; or

subclause.text: constitutes a final order based on a violation of any law or regulation that prohibits fraudulent, manipulative, or deceptive conduct, if such final order was issued within the previous 10-year period; or

clause.text: has been convicted of any felony or misdemeanor in connection with the purchase or sale of any security or involving the making of any false filing with the Commission.

paragraph.text: In this subsection, the term covered regulator means—

subparagraph.text: a State securities commission (or an agency or officer of a State performing like functions);
a State authority that supervises or examines banks, savings associations, or credit unions;
a State insurance commission (or an agency or officer of a State performing like functions);
a Federal banking agency (as defined under section 3 of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act); and

subsection.text: Section 18(b)(4) of the Securities Act of 1933 (15 U.S.C. 77r(b)(4)) is amended—

paragraph.text: in subparagraph (F), by striking or at the end;
in subparagraph (G), by striking the period and inserting ; or; and
by adding at the end the following:
